did.abstract: Beginning in 1970 Mabou Mines produced experimental theatre in the United States and contributed to an international movement in avant-garde, postmodern theatre.The company creates multimedia performances utilizing both existing texts and building performances using a pastiche style that draws on a variety of sources. The materials in the collection document this creative process and the administrative functions necessary to maintain and promote the company. Some of the works by Mabou Mines represented in the collection include Belén: A Book of Hours, Dead End Kids: A History of Nuclear Power, Ecco Porco, Mabou Mines Dollhouse, Red Beads, and Song for New York: What Women Do While Men Sit Knitting.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
did.langmaterial: The majority of the materials are in English. Some publicity materials and scripts are in Czech, French, German, Japanese, Russian, and Spanish.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Mabou Mines is a collaborative, avant-garde theater company based in New York City. Founded in 1970, the company took its name from an old mining town in northern Nova Scotia, near where founding members JoAnne Akalaitis, Lee Breuer, Philip Glass, Ruth Maleczech, and David Warrilow developed The Red Horse Animation, the group's first original performance piece. Since then, Mabou Mines has produced scores of plays; collaborated with writers, musicians, visual artists, and filmmakers; and performed around the globe.

Lee Breuer and Ruth Maleczech met studying theater at UCLA in the late 1950s. Around 1960, the couple hitchhiked to San Francisco to participate in the city's theater scene. Working at the San Francisco Actor's Workshop and the San Francisco Mime Troupe they met Bill Raymond, and at the San Francisco Tape Music Center they met JoAnne Akalaitis. In 1964, Akalaitis moved to New York City but left for Paris soon after with composer (and future husband) Philip Glass. The following year Breuer and Maleczech left San Francisco for Europe. The two couples met up while traveling in Greece, went back to Paris, and with actor David Warrilow, began to work on staging Samuel Beckett's Play. It premiered at the American Cultural Center in 1967. It was also in Paris that the group first met actor Frederick Neumann. In 1969, back in New York with Glass, Akalaitis wrote the others in Paris suggesting they form a theater group in New York.

Influenced by Jerzy Grotowski's teaching and Beckett's work, Mabou Mines went on to produce experimental theater pieces like Breuer's Red Horse Animation, pieces that resulted from intense collaboration and improvisation, and incorporated elements of visual art, dance, mime, puppetry, and music. Arc Welding Piece (1972), for example, featured an artist using an arc welder to make cuts in a large piece of metal, while actors expressed various states of emotion, their faces enlarged by magnifying lenses. In 1974, Fred Neumann joined the group to work on Breuer's second "Animation," The B. Beaver Animation. Bill Raymond joined shortly thereafter. In its early years, Mabou Mines moved between the art world and the theater, often performing in galleries as well as on stages. But its work with Beckett's writing firmly situated the group within a theatrical context. After an early residency at La Mama Experimental Theatre Club in New York, the company began performing at Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, and other venues in New York and elsewhere.

From the beginning, creative roles were fluid and collaboration was key, but Lee Breuer served as the company's primary director. In 1975 however, Akalaitis directed Cascando and opened the door for other members to take on new roles, for the company to expand, and for multiple projects to come together simultaneously. Akalaitis went on to direct Dressed Like an Egg (1977) and Southern Exposure (1979), and wrote and directed Dead End Kids (1980); Neumann directed Mercier and Camier (1979); Maleczech directed Vanishing Pictures (1980). Other performers worked with Mabou Mines, including L.B. Dallas, Linda Hartinian, Ellen McElduff, Greg Mehrten, Terry O'Reilly, and B-St. John Schofield.

The company steadily expanded its repertoire and continued its tradition of collaboration, working with performers and artists, such as composers Bob Telson, John Zorn, Pauline Oliveros, and David Byrne. Mabou Mines has adapted works by Shakespeare (Lear, 1990), Franz Xaver Kroetz (Through the Leaves, 1984) and Help Wanted, 1986), Philip K. Dick (Flow My Tears, The Policeman Said, 1985), and Bertolt Brecht (In the Jungle of Cities, 1991). The company has toured in the United States and abroad.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Fales Library purchased the Mabou Mines Archive from the Mabou Mines Development Foundation in 2003. In 2019, a trunk of posters was located in the repository, accessioned separately, and integrated into the collection as Series XV. The accession number associated with these records is 2019.014. Additional accretions were transferred in 2006, 2008, 2012, 2015, 2017, and 2019; the accession numbers associated with these accretions are 2006.133, 2008.133, 2012.133, 2015.133, 2017.105, and 2019.014.

https://www.maboumines.org/ was selected by the Fales curator and captured through the use of Archive-It. Archive-It uses web crawling technology to capture websites at a scheduled time and displays only an archived copy, from the resulting WARC file, of the website. The accession number associated with this website is 2026.002.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The initial collection of the Mabou Mines Archive (1970-1995) contains materials that document the first 25 years of Mabou Mines, the New York City-based avant-garde theater company. The collection includes materials that document the methods used by Mabou Mines to create theatrical adaptations from existing texts. Collaboration is a key element of Mabou Mines' artistic vision. All decisions, artistic and administrative, large and small, are made by the company members, and each member functions variously as producer, designer, actor, writer, or director. Additionally, all participate as members of the Board of Directors. Materials in the archive reflect this collaborative environment. The collection contains production materials that document all aspects of theatrical production. It includes administrative records that reflect how the organization sustained, promoted, and financially supported its mission. Also included are scripts, programs, photographic documentation, production books, touring files, design plots, posters, and extensive video documentation of most productions. The collection contains correspondence between Samuel Beckett and Ruth Maleczech and Lee Breuer. Known for Mabou Mines' incorporation of technology in theatrical productions, the Mabou Mines Archive contains extensive film, video, and audio production elements and supporting documentation.

The various accretions to the Mabou Mines Archive (1924-2014), processed in 2025, consist of physical and digital materials created and collected by Mabou Mines from the company's founding in 1970 through 2014. These materials continue to document the various productions and residency programs created and supported by the company, and the administrative tasks required for operation. Works by Mabou Mines represented in the collection include Belén: A Book of Hours, Dead End Kids: A History of Nuclear Power, Ecco Porco, Mabou Mines Dollhouse, Red Beads, and Song for New York: What Women Do While Men Sit Knitting. Materials consist of production files (schedules, architectural drawings, lighting and sound cues, and theater programs), directors' and managers' binders, audio and video recordings of rehearsals and final productions, press and reviews of productions and the company, sound and negative film reels for Dead End Kids, scripts, photographs, grant applications and reports, posters, programs and fliers for the residency program, film and theater festival programs, and administrative files, such as correspondence, 122 Community Center (location of the company) Board of Directors' minutes and agendas, and space renovation plans. Earlier shows, from the 1970s-early 1990s, are well represented in the audio and video reels and audiocassette tapes. Productions from the early 2000s are well represented in the born digital materials. All of the materials from these accretions illustrate the mission of Mabou Mines, to support works that are innovative and representative of various experiences and identities.
The archived website also documents Mabou Mines' current and past productions and their development programs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection has been arranged into 17 series, seven of which have been further arranged into subseries. The series and subseries arrangement is as follows:
Subseries III.A. Mabou Mines Stage Productions
Subseries III.B. Mabou Mines Artist-in-Residence Programs
Subseries III.D. Mabou Mines Film Productions
Subseries VIII.A. Touring Files by Production
Subseries IXA. Video Recordings -- Access Copies
Subseries X.B. Company Members and Associates
Series XII. Financial Files, Grants, and Development
For the most part, materials are arranged alphabetically by production title.
During initial processing, Series XII: Financial Files, Grants and Development and Series XIII: Administrative Files were processed at the box level.
All efforts were made to preserve the original arrangement of the collection.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: One copy of the comic book adaptation of Red Horse Animation was removed and catalogued individually in the Fales Library's Downtown Print and Periodicals Collection. This item has been cataloged in NYU's online catalog.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Mabou Mines Archive; MSS 133; box number; folder number or item identifier; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.
To cite the archived websites in this collection: Identification of item, date; Mabou Mines Archive; MSS 133; Wayback URL; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Access to some audiovisual materials in this collection is available through digitized access copies. Researchers may view an item's original container, but the media themselves are not available for playback because of preservation concerns. Materials that have already been digitized are noted in the collection's finding aid and can be requested in our reading room.

Audiovisual materials that have not been preserved may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact NYU Special Collections (special.collections@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596) with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In August 2017, four items were prepared to be moved to offsite art storage in September 2017. Negatives were rehoused in plastic sleeves, and the original labeled sleeve was retained and placed behind the negative. In 2019, 108 posters were located in a trunk and surveyed for preservation needs. Rolled posters were humidified and dried under weight, tears were mended, adhesive residue was reduced, and tape was trimmed. These posters were integrated into the collection as a new series (Series XV) in accordance with the collection's existing arrangement structure. In 2023 45 duplicate VHS were deaccessioned and returned to the donor.

In October 2023, six flat file folders from Creative Time Records were transferred to this collection. In March 2025, container instances for access copies were updated in the inventory. In May 2025, when processing began on the accretions, box 223 was discovered to be missing. Materials were placed into acid-free legal boxes and folders, and oversized materials were rehoused in appropriately sized boxes. Materials in binders were removed from their enclosures, and some items were removed from non-archival sleeves. Duplicate publications, recordings, and documents, publications widely available online or in NYU's catalog holdings, and documents with sensitive personal information were removed. Film elements, such as outtakes, trims, heads, and tails, and unidentified half inch and one-inch audio reels were removed. Previous Oversize Series III, IV, VIII, X, and XII were intellectually integrated into the current series and subseries. Individual items from the processed portion of the Video Recording and Audio Recording Series were nested underneath the production title or added to the alphabetical list intellectually. Existing, processed files in Series XII, XIII, and XVI were renamed "Chronological Financial Files", "Chronological Management Files", and "Chronological Poster Files" respectively, and intellectually incorporated into the arrangement. A flat file folder of Ontological Hysteric Theater posters were transferred to the Richard Foreman and Kate Manheim Papers. Audiovisual materials from box 164 were rehoused into Shared Fales 123 and box 316; three commercial audiocassettes were removed. After rehousing, there is no box 164.

249 CDs, DVDs, floppy disks, and zip disks were forensically imaged, analyzed, and arranged in Forensic Toolkit. The file "!1997ART.IST" in FA_MSS_ER_115 contained a virus; the contents of the file were written to a new file 1997.IST.doc. New York University Libraries follow professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity and authenticity of the content.
In 2025, the archived website was also added to the collection.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: In 2019 it was determined that 45 VHS that were part of accession 2003.133 and used as access copies were in fact duplicates copies of original collection material. In 2023 these duplicates were returned to Mabou Mines.

Off-air recordings, in both analog and digital formats, have been appraised out of the collection due to copyright limitations. These recordings include commercial musical recordings and any recordings from a copyrighted broadcast or television transmission. Broadcast recordings of which Mabou Mines was a producer, director, or participant have been retained. Additionally, set pieces and some costumes were appraised out of the collection due to preservation concerns.

phystech.head: Born-Digital Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. An access terminal for born-digital materials in the collection is available by appointment for reading room viewing and listening only. Researchers may view an item's original container and/or carrier, but the physical carriers themselves are not available for use because of preservation concerns.

appraisal.head: Take Down Policy
appraisal.p: Archived websites are made accessible for purposes of education and research. NYU Libraries have given attribution to rights holders when possible; however, due to the nature of archival collections, we are not always able to identify this information.
If you hold the rights to materials in our archived websites that are unattributed, please let us know so that we may maintain accurate information about these materials.

If you are a rights holder and are concerned that you have found material on this website for which you have not granted permission (or is not covered by a copyright exception under US copyright laws), you may request the removal of the material from our site by submitting a notice, with the elements described below, to the special.collections@nyu.edu.

Please include the following in your notice: Identification of the material that you believe to be infringing and information sufficient to permit us to locate the material; your contact information, such as an address, telephone number, and email address; a statement that you are the owner, or authorized to act on behalf of the owner, of an exclusive right that is allegedly infringed and that you have a good-faith belief that use of the material in the manner complained of is not authorized by the copyright owner, its agent, or the law; a statement that the information in the notification is accurate and made under penalty of perjury; and your physical or electronic signature. Upon receiving a notice that includes the details listed above, we will remove the allegedly infringing material from public view while we assess the issues identified in your notice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains documentation through correspondence of the formation of the company and its early history, fan mail, and other matters. Of particular interest are letters between the playwright Samuel Beckett and company members. The series also includes correspondence with Ellen Stewart, artistic director of LaMaMa E.T.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of original performance programs of Mabou Mines' productions, the Resident Artist Program's productions, the SUITE/space initiative productions, and several Mabou Mines-related productions. In general, if a program lists more than one production, the first-billed production is given precedence. Additional programs and program production elements (descriptions, cast biographies, artwork, etc.) can be found in Series III and Series VIII.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into two subseries, alphabetically by production, then chronologically by performance within each one.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes programs for Mabou Mines' productions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes performance programs from Mabou Mines' residencies; the Resident Artist Program, which provides rehearsal space, a stipend, and mentorship to early-career artists; and the SUITE/Space initiative, which provides space, stipends, and advisement for New York City-based artists of color. Also included are performance programs from productions involving Mabou Mines members, but not produced by the company. Of particular interest is the program from a 1966 performance of Beckett's Play by JoAnne Akalaitis, Lee Breuer, and company, pre-Mabou Mines.

physdesc.extent: in 28 manuscript boxes, 24 record cartons, 2 small flat boxes, 8 large flat boxes, and 59 oversize flat file folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of the production files for most of Mabou Mines' stage productions; Re-Cher-Chez, the Resident Artist Program (RAP), and SUITE/Space, the company's early studio for avant-garde performing arts, and its two artists-in-residence/theater-training programs; related productions; and Mabou Mines' film productions. Materials include correspondence (see Series IB for additional production-specific correspondence); rights and royalties agreements; artist agreements and contracts; production descriptions and summaries; research material; script elements; artist and cast biographies; program production elements; press releases and postcards; grant applications and other development and fundraising materials; financial records including budgets and box-office records; national touring information; technical specifications; audio specifications and cue sheets; lighting plots, cue sheets, gels, and gobos; stage plots and schematics; and costume and prop design and information.

did.unittitle: Subseries III.A. Mabou Mines Stage Productions

physdesc.extent: in 24 manuscript boxes, 16 record cartons, 2 small flat boxes, 8 large flat boxes, and 59 flat file folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of production files of Mabou Mines productions from 1970-2012.

Subseries III.D. Mabou Mines Film Productions

physdesc.extent: in 5 manuscript boxes, 8 record cartons, and 1 large flat box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series mostly consists of notes and dailies for the film version of Dead End Kids. There is additional material on the film version of Mabou Mines Dollhouse, a proposed film version of The Gospel at Colonus, and the documentary on the making of Mabou Mines Lear, referred to as the "Lear Tapes". Materials include proposals, budgets, logs, and correspondence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into sub-sub-series alphabetically, chronologically within each one.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bulk this series is comprised of professionally produced 8" x 10" black-and-white prints of performances, sets, and performers. Other size prints, contact sheets, negatives, color snapshots, and photographers' labels make up the rest of this series. Most prints and contact sheets are clearly marked with the photographer's name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of documentary photographs of many Mabou Mines productions. Prints usually appear before negatives or contact sheets. There is a semblance of chronology, though many photographs are undated.

arrangement.head: Arrangement

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of final scripts, drafts, notes, film treatments, and screenplays representing a majority of Mabou Mines' productions and some Mabou Mines-affiliated productions. Of particular interest are the many drafts and early versions of Lee Breuer's works, scripts notated by Ruth Maleczech, and a monologue written by Samuel Beckett for David Warrilow. Also included are other original writings by Lee Breuer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of the contents of binders and folders that variously included scripts, notes, cues, contact sheets, and schedules, usually heavily annotated. These books were often compiled by a stage manager or director in order to be used during production of a play. Several Mabou Mines' productions, and some Mabou Mines-affiliated productions, are represented. There is significant overlap with Series III: Production Files. Of particular interest are the contents of binders used by JoAnne Akalaitis during production of the Dead End Kids film.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of records of Mabou Mines performances outside of New York City, including national and international tours. Series materials include schedules, correspondence with theaters and venues, lists of technical requirements, press releases, touring inquiries, travel information (e.g., correspondence with travel agencies and airlines), and festival programs.

did.unittitle: Subseries VIII.A. Touring Files by Production

physdesc.extent: in 5 manuscript boxes, 3 record cartons, 2 large flat boxes, 13 flat file folders, and 1 object

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials in this subseries consist of tour schedules and itineraries; budgets; contracts; lighting plots, track sheets, and cues; ground plans and stage schematics of various venues; and press releases. There is significant overlap with the materials in Series III: Production Files.

physdesc.extent: in 10 manuscript boxes, 4 record cartons, 1 small flat box, 3 large flat boxes, and 2 flat file folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains numerous published articles written about Mabou Mines. There are original newspaper clippings, photocopies of clippings, magazine and journal articles, press releases, production histories, programs, and other related material. Materials include performance reviews, interviews, performance listings and advertisements, and articles about members and the company in general.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: When the collection was maintained by Mabou Mines, the newspaper reviews for some productions had been individually foldered and each given a rating based on its favorability. This rating system was expressed through the use of color-coded circle stickers attached to the tops of some folders. Rave reviews were given red or orange stickers, yellow stickers were for mixed reviews, and black were for negative reviews. Presumably, this enabled those working at Mabou Mines to quickly determine the general critical opinion of a given performance, and also served as a shortcut to finding reviews from which to pull quotes for press releases, advertisements, etc. This rating system was not retained when the collection was processed at Fales Library for the following reasons: (1) the researcher is better served if several reviews of a performance are collected into a single folder; (2) the rating system was not uniformly applied; (3) some colored stickers had fallen off before the series was processed; (4) a reader can distinguish a rave from a pan.

physdesc.extent: in 2 manuscript boxes, 1 record carton, 1 small flat box, and 3 large flat boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes articles and clippings about Mabou Mines generally, followed by published mentions of the company's awards and nominations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged first by general Mabou Mines articles, then by articles on awards, chronologically within each one.

physdesc.extent: in 9 manuscript boxes, 3 record cartons, 1 small flat box, 2 large flat boxes, and 2 flat file folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of original and photocopied clippings and articles about various Mabou Mines' productions. The designation "Beckett Plays" refers to any combination of Come and Go, The Lost Ones, and Play, which were often performed together in the company's early days. The company used this designation for the numerous published items that mention one or all of these plays, and it was retained for this series. In other series each Beckett production is referred to by its individual title.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by production, then chronologically by performance.

physdesc.extent: in 1 record carton, 2 custom puppet boxes, 3 oversized flat boxes, 4 object boxes, 1 custom box, 1 tube, and 2 containers without profiles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of objects and props from Mabou Mines productions. Of particular interest are the puppets Rose (Shaggy Dog Animation) and John (Prelude to Death in Venice), and the shadow puppets from The MahabharANTa.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The shadow puppets 133.2.0023 through 133.2.0053 were made for The MahabharANTa, written by Lee Breuer and performed in 1992 in the United States. Larry Reed facilitated the collaboration between Lee Breuer and Balinese shadow master (dalang), I Wayan Wija. Wija made the rawhide puppets in 1992 in Bali. In an interview, he said he made all the puppets, except the wooden handles, which were custom-made by local artisans. Shadow puppets made of paper and found materials were not created by I Wayan Wija.
Source: Wija, I Wayan. 2023. Interview by Peiyuan Sun and Jessica Pace. WhatsApp. February 13, 2023.

did.unittitle: John--A Prelude to Death in Venice

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John the puppet measures 51" long, 19" wide, 8" deep, and is stored in box 340. The puppet has brown hair and is dressed in a navy blue knitted cap, a red scarf tied around the neck, light blue button down shirt, brown leather jacket, blue jeans, navy blue socks, and black leather shoes. John does not have arms or hands. In the play, the actor inserts their hands into John's sleeves and uses them as John's hands. John was designed and constructed by Linda Hartinian.

John's accessories include a navy blue knit beanie hat, a navy blue T-shirt with a boys' summer camp logo, a Kodak camera, a striped corduroy cushion, a beige band with a blue tie closure, and foam knee pads with velcro straps that were likely used by his puppeteer (all stored in box 349).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: Rose, a puppet created by Linda Hartinian, measures 44" long, 15" wide, 6" deep, and is stored in box 341. Rose has long, dark brown hair and is dressed in a long-sleeved black jumpsuit with black corduroy shoes.

Rose's accessories include a painted head with two detachable wigs, a blue turtleneck and jeans, red sneakers and white socks, blue beaded elastic bands, a pink satin heart (all stored in box 348), a fur-lined denim jacket, a taxidermied paw, a gray sweatsuit, a black and metallic-colored kimono, beige satin cushions embroidered with red roses, and a beige satin band with velcro, and clear plastic poles used to control the puppet (all stored in box 361). Rose's costumes were created by Sally Rosen and Dru-ann Chukram.

Rose's head is double-sided, featuring two distinct faces. The first is painted a pale yellow-beige color with a long, wavy brown wig and the second face, directly on the other side, seemingly depicts an older woman. It has a slightly darker, more pink skin tone and a long, wavy gray wig. A wooden dowel is attached to the bottom of the double-sided head.
Rose's fur-lined denim jacket is split vertically along the back from the bottom hem to its collar to accommodate Rose's puppeteer.

physdesc.extent: in 13 manuscript boxes, 22 record cartons, 1 small flat box, 4 large flat boxes, and 2 flat file folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to the daily administrative tasks required to manage the company. Materials consist of 122 Community Center Board of Directors' meeting minutes, agendas and correspondence; Mabou Mines Board of Directors' meeting minutes, agendas, and correspondence; general correspondence; intern and job announcements; space renovations; notes and notebooks; mailings; and fliers and brochures about the company. Also included are programs and correspondence related to conferences in which Mabou Mines' members participated and workshops and teaching intensives hosted by Mabou Mines.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of performance posters from various venues, the majority of which are offset litho prints with a small number of electrostatic prints and photostats. Some posters show original mockup art with ink and graphite on board or with a thin tracing overlay. Also included are posters from theater festivals, conferences, and workshops in which Mabou Mines participated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series mostly consists of 16 mm film reels and film elements from the film version of Dead End Kids. Additionally, there are a few outtakes from Imagination Dead Imagine and another film by JoAnne Akalaitis, "Other Children".

unittitle.emph: Dead End Kids: A History of Nuclear Power
Dead End Kids: A History of Nuclear Power

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The archived website contains information on their current works in production, productions in development, and descriptions of their works dating back to 1970. The website also includes information on the SUITE/space program, the Ruth Maleczech Award, and the Resident Artist Program.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: New site crawls are accrued annually.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Full-Text searches of archived websites are available at https://archive-it.org/organizations/567.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Crawl was limited to domains and subdomains of maboumines.org in order to remain within the collection scope and data constraints.
